metadata.description:
Penny Spezzano is an Author, Angel Artist, she does Angel Circles, is a Family Woman, loves Animals and is an Angel Reader. 
She can be seen at http://www.RhoseConnection.com/angel 
Contact her at: penny@rhoseconnection.com

metadata.description:
Sermon for the 22nd Sunday after Pentecost, 2014 - "Three Views of Ten Talents"

Matthew 25:14-30

9. November, 2014

Reconciliation Ministries. Anthony Mark LaMort, Pastor.

While we are recognized by the State of New Jersey and the United States Federal Government as a religious institution, we are not part of any denomination. We consider ourselves to members of the larger Family of God. 

We are a Christ-centered, Biblically based church that recognizes and respects the diversity of individuals and groups while striving towards the unity of all people in Christ, for in Christ there is no slave or free, Jew or Gentile, male or female. (Galatians 3:28)

At Reconciliation Church, everyone is welcome, regardless of age, race, gender, orientation, religious affiliation or lack thereof. The saving Gospel of Peace is for all people: He is the atoning sacrifice for our sins, and not only for ours but also for the sins of the whole world. (1 John 2:2)

We strive to be 'bringers of the Light of Christ' -- 'Ambassadors for Christ'; believing that all this is from God, who reconciled us to himself through Christ and gave us the ministry of reconciliation: that God was reconciling the world to himself in Christ, not counting people's sins against them. And he has committed to us the message of reconciliation. We are therefore Christ's ambassadors, as though God were making his appeal through us. (2 Corinthians 5:1-20)

All static images are believed to be in the Public Domain or otherwise utilized under fair use.

metadata.creator: KRON-TV
metadata.description:
This is a copy of a TV documentary report, "The People and the Police: Oakland", produced by KRON-TV. A copy of the film was acquired by the U.S. Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), transferred to the National Archives and Records Administration (NARA) as part of the FBI archives, and then digitized by NARA and published online here: https://catalog.archives.gov/id/12120

NARA described the film as follows: "TELEVISION NEWS PROGRAM: This film is about police brutality in Oakland, California, 1974. Narrator talks about how town was over half black in 1960's and police force was all white. How blacks were generally treated with disrespect. Some of the policemen interviewed say they were hired as super cops and did not want to change way things were run. Changes were implemented, blacks were hired, and blacks in the community were beginning to feel a change as older policemen were told to less aggressive or be fired. Action Review Panel was set up to review police community relations. Several incidents resulting in arrest of blacks and charges of disorderly conduct were heard by panel. Speaking in this film is Ron Dellums and police chief, George Hart. Song, "Hey, You Old Oakland Town" is heard as camera scans streets and black community of Oakland."
